job_title: Director of Operations in Seattle, WA
pros: Green River is a stable community college that has an amazing student services and good programs for students. It is a financially stable college, with a lot to offer. They will weather hard times a little bit easier than other colleges in the WA area during an upcoming recession or decrease in enrollment/tuition.
cons: There are long-standing people who have been at the college who don't want to try new things that are now pretty standard at other colleges for the past 5 years. In 15 years, this college will be amazing. But until those people leave or retire, there wont be any significant change.

pros: Very helpful staff and especially Advisors
cons: Financial aid can be a frustrating process.

pros: The faculty and staff are dedicated to service to the students and at the leading edge of understanding DEI within the context of higher education.
cons: Students are busy with life and often have other concerns besides learning.

pros: Great co-workers, fairly flexible schedule. Benefits. Union workplace.
cons: A lot of politics. Management is actively afraid of a Faculty uprising. Fear based decision making. No opportunities for growth. No opportunities for professional development. Broken promises. Favoritism and nepotism run rampant. Only way to get ahead is to actively subvert your own rights. Some managers are extremely negligent of their departments and will only show up to take credit for the work but disappear when things are going poorly. Blame based culture. Any successes you may have will be immediately overshadowed because someone didn't like the font you used in an email.

pros: Great group of people, the college is striving to be a positive ally in the fight for social justice and equity for call students and staff.
cons: Green River was not really prepared when the pandemic hit, we had barely any services or classes offered online for students. However now I hope they continue the online options because some students would prefer that to in-person.

pros: Learn and experience a lot
cons: Don't really think there's a downside working there

pros: Flexible, decent wage, good supervisor and work environment
cons: Couldn't find any major cons

pros: I enjoyed working there for 13 years. I mostly taught online so it was nice to be able to work from home. I also was able to learn multiple online teaching platforms--Blackboard and Canvas-- which increased my marketability for teaching online at other colleges.
cons: The downside of working at Green River was not so much Green River itself, but more the downside of working as an adjunct. When only a few people signed up for courses, classes would be cancelled. Or the full-time instructors would get the job because they didn't want to pay the adjuncts.

review_title: Green River College PC Repair Intern
pros: Working at Green River Community College PC Repair Shop is a great opportunity to compliment you IT studies and gain experience troubleshooting PC and Laptop problems. You also get customer service experience in taking and returning phone calls from potential customers inquiring about services available and interacting with current customers and their concerns. It is rewarding to know you are helping them become more proactive in understanding the importance of keeping their machines security up to date.
cons: There was not too much to not like working at the PC Repair shop, except for the close quarters (square footage)  work area the college allotted for doing repairs with the many interns as the program is popular.

review_title: Green River Community College - a college of diversity, change and opportunity.
pros: Working with a diverse student population and collegues who care about students.  Staff also have the opportunity to help with a number of different activities on campus.
cons: There could be more staff to help with the large population of students.  Some students have little to no technology skills and carry with them some anxiety that hurts them in the long run.  Can be stressful working with students who need basic skills, ESL training and have unrealistic educational/career expectations.

job_title: International Student Programmer in Auburn, WA
pros:
Great coworkers. Everyone was very helpful and supportive and it really made my time enjoyable.
Learnt a lot during my time. This was actually my first office/desk job but it was really fun. My supervisors were excellent people who were always willing to help too.
Office culture was good. Everyone was respectful and there are was a lot of diversity in the office.
cons:
Nothing much really...

However, opportunities for advancement is limited... You need a lot of working time and qualifications to be promoted. Training was only a month long but I felt like that was sufficient for my job. 

In other words, I still really enjoyed my time here!

pros: The staff and faculty and students are great.  There is a diverse student body.
cons: The administration is getting rid of longterm tenured faculty and staff and creating a hostile work environment. They have given themselves 30% salary increases while faculty have seen none in over 7 years.  They shamelessly recruit international students because of the revenue they bring, without any regard for the experience these students seek (studying with American students, not themselves in a different country) nor the needs of the local community they are meant to serve.  Beware.

pros: Great benefits for those who work for the state and lots of sick leave and vacation days to balance slightly lower than market rate pay.
cons: Some of the areas work in silos without much interaction or concern for what's going on elsewhere, and you have to be proactive to be the change to make it a collaborative environment. That said, it can easily be done.

review_title: Very tough place if you seek growth
pros: It's a job in a nice setting. There is a great staff from the Director levels down
cons: There is a very sick culture, from which the animosity can be felt. It's a top down and very controlling environment at the senior level. Program Directors are not allowed to lead their respective departments, and in fact the tension is very high. Faculty are unionized and definitely flex their muscles. Senior managers are very close minded to new information and other approaches to management. It's more of a façade that can be seen at the surface level. Employees gave up a 3% pay deduction and were given 1% raises from the deducted amounts, to convince them they received raises.

review_title: If you love personal interaction with students, you will like this job!
pros: Good working conditions and supervisors are very open to suggestions and ideas.
cons: The parking situation on campus is horrible, at best! Since this is in a wooded area and night fall occurs early during Fall and Winter quarters, there needs to be more lighting around the campus.

review_title: Let Go Without Reason - Continuing Ed.
pros: Campus is nice and quite. Good location if you live nearby.
cons:
Let go without any warning or reason near the end of my probation period. From other former employees I have spoken to, this is common.
Job description was nearly 100% false. Turned out to be a glorified receptionist taking student registration most of the time or printing off documents for Continuing Ed instructors.
Management was rude and unwilling to teach, especially after only 2 days of cross training with previous coordinator before they left after being there for years.
Not fully explained required tasks or standards, then blamed if not done 100% correctly while still learning the position.
Union, which initially said they would try and find placement for me elsewhere in the college, but wen't silent after my last day. Never told as to why let go.
Felt like no one truly cared about the department. Manager was planning on quitting after less than a year of taking over the position. Same manager also rifled through personal documents and belongings and even took personal documents while meeting with Union to be told of termination of my position.
Terrible shift hours. Usually onsite from 10AM to 7PM and often had to stay late as some Continuing Ed classes didn't begin until that time and needed support or help.

pros: Very comfortable and warm work environment. There is a very strong sense of teamwork that simultaneously contributes to self-development.  Management is very understanding and always willing to explain and clarify certain duties.
cons: There tend to sometimes be some unclarity in terms of structure and job description.

pros: Academic atmosphere and interactions with students were energizing. Some faculty and adjunct faculty were great to work with and treated you as a colleague and not a subordinate; classified staff were friendly and helpful.
cons: Administration supported a work environment that was unprofessional and toxic; situations of aggressive faculty behavior goes uncorrected even after there is a known historical pattern.

pros: This was my first job out of college. Great management, was able to transfer to another campus to get more hours and a raise. Overall really enjoyed my time there.
cons: Stingy on the hours and benefits that come with it - but understandable as I was hired for a part time position.

pros: It is really nice to work with the International Program Department, you get to learn a lot from your peers and learn to help solve students problem.
cons: You might not know every answers to the questions, so do not hesitate to ask your supervisor or peers. Bring up students problem to help solve problem.

review_title: State Institution with great benefits, but poorly managed
pros:
Great benefits
Beautiful campus
Working with/ for students is inspiring and fun
Access to a lot of interesting events and people
cons:
Poor morale
Leadership vision/ goals do not align with real challenges faced by Institution.
Financial struggles exacerbate underlying poor management
